item.title: South Korea Doubts North’s Claim It Detonated Hydrogen Bomb
item.description: Officials and analysts in the South say that the estimated yield, or energy, from the explosion appeared to be too small to be that of such a weapon.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:credit: South Korean Presidential Blue House, via Getty Images
item.media:description: President Park Geun-hye of South Korea, center, convened an urgent meeting of her top national security aides in Seoul, South Korea, on Wednesday.

item.title: Jeremy Corbyn, British Labour Leader, Finishes Shadow Cabinet Reorganization
item.description: Mr. Corbyn’s reshuffling produced only minor changes after two days of internal argument, as he held off on a major purge of internal dissenters.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: The leader of Britain’s opposition Labour Party, Jeremy Corbyn, leaving his home in London on Tuesday.

item.title: Pierre Boulez, French Composer, Dies at 90
item.description: Mr. Boulez belonged to an extraordinary generation of European composers who, while in their 20s, came to the forefront during the decade or so after World War II.
item.dc:creator: PAUL GRIFFITHS
item.media:credit: Hiroyuki Ito for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pierre Boulez leading the Met Orchestra at Carnegie Hall in New York in 2010.

item.title: Q. and A.: Did North Korea Detonate a Hydrogen Bomb? Here’s What We Know
item.description: A closer read of the country’s announcement on Wednesday, whether it can be verified and its previous detonations.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: People in Seoul, South Korea, watched a news report on North Korea's announcement of its first hydrogen bomb test on Wednesday.

item.title: Letter From America: Avoiding the Dreaded ‘Second-Term Curse’
item.description: Political observers say that President Obama appears to have avoided the pitfalls that often undermine a second presidential term.
item.dc:creator: JOHN HARWOOD
item.media:description: President Obama in Newark in November. The durability of Mr. Obama’s second-term legacy depends partly on his successor.

item.title: Saudi Executions Seen as Sending Message to All Dissenters
item.description: Putting to death accused Qaeda militants along with advocates for the Shiite minority suggested that the Saudis were willing to endure the high political costs.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: The aftermath of a raid by Saudi security forces on accused Qaeda militants in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, in 2004. Saudi officials said the 47 prisoners executed over the weekend included accused Qaeda terrorists who carried out deadly attacks in the kingdom more than a decade ago.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Putin’s Year in Scandals
item.description: Russia is a mafia state, not only because it is run like the mafia but also because it is run by organized crime.
item.dc:creator: MASHA GESSEN

item.title: India Says All 6 Gunmen Have Been Killed in Pathankot Air Base Attack
item.description: Security forces were searching the sprawling Indian Air Force base for explosives on Tuesday, the fourth day of the operation.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR
item.media:description: Indian police at the air base in Pathankot, Punjab, on Tuesday.

item.title: North Korea Says It Has Detonated Its First Hydrogen Bomb
item.description: The claim, if true, would drastically escalate the nuclear challenge from one of the world’s most isolated and dangerous states.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER and CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: A screen showing the reports of an earthquake near North Korea's nuclear plant on Wednesday. North Korea said it had detonated its first hydrogen bomb.

item.title: North Korea Announces That It Has Detonated First Hydrogen Bomb
item.description: The claim, if true, would dramatically escalate the nuclear challenge from one of the world’s most isolated and dangerous states.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: A map released by the United States Geological Survey shows the location and intensity of the earthquake detected on Tuesday.

item.title: Open Source: Cricket Star Fined for Propositioning TV Reporter During Live Interview
item.description: Chris Gayle, a Jamaican cricketer, sparked outrage online by asking Mel McLaughlin, a female reporter, to join him for a drink during an interview.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: World Briefing: Nigeria: Former Minister Is Charged With Corruption
item.description: A former defense minister has been charged with corruption in connection with the diversion of $1.5 million intended for military spending, the government said.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Central African Republic: U.N. Requests Inquiry Into Peacekeepers
item.description: The United Nations has asked for an investigation into new accusations that United Nations peacekeepers sexually abused four underage girls in Bangui, the capital of the Central African Republic.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Central African Republic: Two Presidential Candidates Are Almost Tied
item.description: Partial results for national elections in the Central African Republic showed that there had been a high voter turnout and that two candidates were running neck in neck.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Britain: Parliament to Debate Closing Border to Trump
item.description: British lawmakers will debate a petition that calls for the Republican presidential candidate Donald J. Trump to be barred from Britain.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Saudi-Iran Feud Poses Threat to Iraq’s Effort to Combat ISIS
item.description: As Iraq faces the challenge of routing ISIS, it is confronted with a conflict between Iran and Saudi Arabia that threatens to inflame sectarian tensions.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD ANNE BARNARD and SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: Iraqi government forces and elite counter-terrorism service carried an injured person during battles with ISIS in Ramadi, on Monday.

item.title: Reports of Attacks on Women in Germany Heighten Tension Over Migrants
item.description: The reports of assaults on New Year’s Eve in Cologne set off a national outcry after the police described the attackers as young men “who appeared to have a North African or Arabic” background.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: A police car at the central train station in Cologne, Germany, on Tuesday.

item.title: Gulf States Guarding Their Interests in Saudi-Iran Rift
item.description: Many countries signaled that they would take a measured approach, sympathizing with Saudi Arabia, a powerful ally, but also trying to avoid a conflict with Iran.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: Smoke rose from the Saudi Embassy during a demonstration in Tehran on Saturday.

item.title: Venezuela Opposition Takes Reins of Assembly as Tensions Rise
item.description: The opposition achieved a landslide victory in elections in early December, winning two-thirds of the 167 seats in the Assembly and breaking with a long period of domination by the socialist movement.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM NEUMAN and NICHOLAS CASEY
item.media:description: A woman confronted a Bolivarian National Guard at an opposition rally in Caracas, Venezuela, on Tuesday.

item.title: World Briefing: Jordan: Thousands of Syrian Refugees Are Stranded
item.description: Jordan said that over 12,000 Syrian refugees had amassed at its border, awaiting entry into the country.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
